content.title: Lymphedema - Comprehensive Overview
content.summary: Chronic accumulation of protein-rich interstitial fluid due to lymphatic insufficiency, causing progressive limb swelling and tissue changes if untreated.

definitions.definition: Chronic, progressive condition characterized by accumulation of protein-rich fluid in tissues due to impaired lymphatic transport, causing swelling, tissue fibrosis, and immunocompromise.
Lymphedema resulting from developmental abnormalities of the lymphatic system: congenital (Milroy disease), praecox (onset before 35), or tarda (onset after 35).
Lymphedema resulting from damage to previously normal lymphatics: surgery, radiation, infection (filariasis), trauma, or malignancy.

key_concepts.explanation: Stage 0: Subclinical, no visible swelling. Stage I: Early, pitting edema, reversible with elevation. Stage II: Non-pitting, does not resolve with elevation. Stage III (elephantiasis): Extreme swelling, skin changes, tissue fibrosis.

Stemmer sign: inability to pinch skin fold at base of second toe (positive indicates lymphedema). Bilateral limb measurements for quantification. Pitting vs non-pitting assessment. Skin changes: hyperkeratosis, papillomatosis.

Complete Decongestive Therapy: manual lymphatic drainage (MLD), compression bandaging, exercises, skin care. Two phases: intensive (reduction) and maintenance. Mainstay of treatment for most patients.
Physiologic: lymphovenous anastomosis (LVA), vascularized lymph node transfer (VLNT). Ablative/debulking: liposuction, excisional procedures (Charles). Surgery is adjunctive, not curative.

evidence.citation: Koshima et al., Lymphovenous Anastomosis Series, 2000
evidence.finding: Supermicrosurgical LVA reduces limb volume and infection frequency in early-stage lymphedema

evidence.citation: Brorson et al., Liposuction for Lymphedema, 2006
evidence.finding: Liposuction achieves significant volume reduction when fat is the predominant tissue component

clinical_pearls: Positive Stemmer sign strongly suggests lymphedema but negative does not exclude it
Cellulitis frequency increases with advanced staging - prophylactic antibiotics may be needed
Compression is lifelong - compliance correlates with outcomes
LVA works best in early stages before extensive fibrosis develops
Breast cancer-related lymphedema is the most common cause in developed countries
learning_objectives: Apply ISL staging criteria to classify severity
Describe components of Complete Decongestive Therapy
Compare physiologic and ablative surgical options
